title: Winter Heating Bills Loom as the Next Inflation Threat
content: After plunging during the pandemic as the economy slowed, energy prices have roared upward. Washington is already moving to offer homeowners relief.

title: Retailers Scramble to Attract Workers Ahead of the Holidays
content: Signing bonuses, higher wages, even college tuition. Companies are using perks to entice new employees in an industry that has been battered by the pandemic.

more_info.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery

title: Starbucks Seeks to Delay Union Election as Vote Nears
content: The move, and a visit by the company’s former chief executive days before the scheduled start of balloting at three Buffalo-area stores, reflect the stakes.

title: Behind Elon Musk’s Twitter Poll Is a Tax Bill Coming Due
content: He asked whether he should sell 10 percent of his stock, and Twitter voters said yes. Stock options he was granted in 2012 are “a ticking tax time bomb,” one expert said.

title: Americans Are Flush With Cash and Jobs. They Also Think the Economy Is Awful.
content: The psychological effects of inflation seem to have the upper hand.

title: Why the Media Loves Labor Now
content: At a moment of political turmoil, economic change and a pandemic-driven focus on how we work, labor has become a hot news beat.

title: Can Progress on Diversity Be Union-Made?
content: In Boston, setting a goal for a racially diverse construction work force is one thing. Meeting it has proved more difficult.

more_info.byline: By Eduardo Porter and Tony Luong

title: How Public Preschool Can Help, and How to Make Sure It Doesn’t Hurt
content: Congress is considering universal pre-K and subsidies for child care. Research shows how these policies can benefit children, and when they can backfire.

title: U.S. Urges Court Not to Block Vaccine Mandate on Employers
content: The Biden Justice Department filed its case before an appeals court that has temporarily halted the measure.

title: With Tears, Hugs and Balloons, U.S. Allows Vaccinated Foreign Travelers to Enter
content: On Monday, after more than 18 months, restrictions that kept families separated and cost the global travel industry hundreds of billions of dollars were lifted.

more_info.byline: By Ceylan Yeginsu, Heather Murphy and Concepción de León

title: The Fed warns of social media ‘echo chambers’ that pump up meme stocks.
content: A Federal Reserve report found the financial system showed broad signs of resilience, but it suggested so-called meme stocks could pose some risks.

title: Wirecutter workers threaten a walkout during a peak shopping week over contract delays.
content: Their union, which is seeking higher salary minimums and guaranteed raises, has been negotiating with The New York Times Company for two years.

title: Randal Quarles, formerly the Fed’s vice chair for supervision, will leave the central bank at the end of December.
content: Mr. Quarles’s term as a governor could have stretched until 2032. His departure will give the Biden administration more room to remake the Fed.

title: Elon Musk’s ‘Ticking Tax Time Bomb’
content: Is the Tesla chief about to sell a big chunk of his shares?

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: Paytm, a payments company, is aiming to raise $2.5 billion amid India’s stock boom.
content: One97 Communications, the app’s parent company, has drawn interest from institutional investors as online shopping in India expands.

title: The Popularity of E-Bikes Isn’t Slowing Down
content: Motorized bicycles are outselling all-electric cars and have the potential to transform urban transit.

title: Chip Shortage Creates New Power Players
content: Low-profile chip makers with aging factories have become surprisingly powerful, leading to industry changes that may outlive the pandemic-fueled supply crunch.

title: The Biden administration is ‘prepared to defend’ the vaccine rules for big employers, the surgeon general says.
content: The administration last week set Jan. 4 as the deadline for companies with 100 or more employees to mandate Covid vaccinations or implement weekly testing of workers.

title: International travelers eagerly await reunions with their loved ones as the U.S. travel changes near.
content: On Monday, travelers from many other countries who are fully vaccinated against the coronavirus will be allowed to enter the United States.

title: The Week in Business: Time to Slow the Economic Stimulus
content: Jobs rebounded in October. The government finally issued rules on requiring vaccinations at big employers. And we'll see how quickly inflation is rising.

title: Berkshire Hathaway’s Profit Fell in the Third Quarter
content: The conglomerate’s results reflected the turmoil in financial markets and the broader slowdown in U.S. economic growth.

title: An Environmental Hero or Outlaw? Can It Be Both?
content: Steven Donziger, who won a $9.5 billion settlement against Chevron over dumped oil, began serving a six-month sentence for contempt of court last week.

title: If You Sell ‘Oaxaca in a Bottle,’ What Happens to Oaxaca?
content: Mezcal is soaring in popularity far from the agave fields in Mexico.

title: Democrats Choosing Less Risky Path on Drug Prices
content: Experts say recent compromises could create less harm in balancing innovation with profits.

title: Aaron Feuerstein, Mill Owner Who Refused to Leave, Dies at 95
content: After a fire devastated his Massachusetts factory in 1995, he kept paying his employees and spent hundreds of millions to rebuild.

title: Boeing directors reach a settlement in a shareholder lawsuit over the 737 Max crashes.
content: The $237.5 million accord is subject to court approval. The plaintiffs said board members had neglected their oversight duties.

des_facet: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

title: In Fate of Oil Field, Climate Activists and Energy Executives See Future
content: What is Cambo? It’s a proposed oil field deep underwater off Scotland that has become an intense focus of environmentalists and the energy industry.

title: What to Expect at Work When You’re Expecting
content: Legal protections against pregnancy discrimination are one thing. Actual feelings of security are another.

title: Congress Is Investigating McKinsey Over Its Role in the Opioid Crisis
content: A House committee has requested documents related to the firm’s advice to drug makers and potential conflicts of interest with the F.D.A.

more_info.byline: By Walt Bogdanich and Michael Forsythe
org_facet: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

title: At Hunter Biden’s Art Show, Line, Color and Questions
content: Paintings by the president’s son are drawing visitors to a gallery in SoHo, and also criticism from those who worry that purchasers might hope to be buying not just art, but access.

title: Our reporters are breaking down the jobs numbers.
When Bad News About the Climate Is Good for Green Stocks
content: Markets respond when coverage of global warming spikes, new research suggests. But investors could become inured to the bleak state of climate change.

title: Google Temps Fought Loss of Pandemic Bonus. And Won.
content: When a Google staffing agency reneged on a promise to pay an attendance bonus, temps who are part of the company’s union organized and forced it to backtrack.
